@archmagefi_ hey! I‚Äôm using your archmage-finance theGraph endpoint for my @yewbow_  interface.

I have a few questions about your implementation. Please DM me, would be greatly appreciated :)
@AncapSansad I used @matplotlib to create a graph at each transaction, each one saved as a PNG image. Then I used @FFmpeg to combine those images into a movie.
@curcio_ml Would using uni v3 positions to "hedge" squeeth make money then?

@StittsHappening @DefiEdge Not sure if collecting fees scales linearly with the number of positions since you only need to sign the transaction once.
@DefiEdge: how does that work on https://t.co/uPFobXBmSK?

11/ It is easy to see how this approach can be generalized to neutralize the gamma of any (positive convexity) payoff function.

Power perp? Log perp? Exponential perp? Long options? Binary options? The gamma for all of them could be hedged using Uni v3.

Happy hedging! üå≤üå≤üå≤üå≤

10/ Deploying 8 LP positions may cost a lot of gas, but it could easily be done using a Decentralized Asset Management tool like @DefiEdge

For instance, 4 LP positions can be deployed at the same time in on https://t.co/OKsd3Mi5rI (I'm told >5 positions will be enabled soon) https://t.co/ek2pSoqtpi

9/ Hedging the delta of the combined position results in a payoff curve that's flat in both value and delta (in green below) across the entire range of the LP positions.

It is thus possible to construct a fully hedged squeeth whose value stays constant over any arbitrary range. https://t.co/2SH72bQveP

8/ Deploying several Uni v3 LP position with the right liquidity makes the gamma of the LP position exactly equal to -2, thereby neutralizing squeeth's gamma = 2

The approximation can be improved by adding more LP positions. I'm showing an example using 8 positions. https://t.co/SqBLIci9U7

7/ In other words, they can be used as the basis of what I call the Gamma Transform, which can be used to approximate any payoffs with negative convexity as the linear combination of several 1-tick positions.

Let's apply this to squeeth, whose gamma is always equal to 2

6/ Why do we care? 1-tick positions can be seen as a Kronecker delta, which is zero everywhere and with an area equal to 1 at the current tick.

Since each 1-tick position have no overlap and they are all independent of one another, they can be used to approximate any function: https://t.co/8WwZU5M42X

5/ More specifically, its shape looks like a rectangle of width 2K*(r-1). To keep the area under that curve equal to unity, the height of that rectangle needs to be -1/(2K*(r-1)): https://t.co/vffYOvfJGT

4/ If we look at the gamma of a Uni v3 LP position, then things get interesting: both gamma and delta are discontinuous at the upper and low price, but the Gamma of a single-tick Uni v3 position looks (almost) like a rectangle as the range factor approaches 1 https://t.co/lzk9LcOsgV

3/ Now let's consider squeeth, a recently released financial product by the @Opyn team. 

Squeeth is a type of power perpetual whose return is equal to the square of the price of ETH (squeeth = square-eth)

It's gamma is constant at all price and always equal to 2: https://t.co/4NTreR85i8

2/ Formally, Gamma is defined as the second derivative of the value of an asset. Recall that delta is the first derivative of the value of an asset

Delta = slope, Gamma = slope of the slope

Here's the gamma and delta for a positive convexity instrument like a long call option. https://t.co/afiptMuq9J

1/ First, what is gamma? Gamma is a measure of the "convexity" of an asset. 
An asset with a positive convexity will increase in value faster as its price goes up. OTOH, an asset with negative convexity will see diminishing returns.
Here's a graph showing how gamma affects price: https://t.co/A8pzR7DlSN

I just published: "Gamma transforms: How to hedge squeeth using Uni¬†V3"

We demonstrate how 1-tick Uni v3 LP positions can perfectly hedge the gamma of positive convexity assets like squeeth.

Gamma transforms? squeeth? convexity?

Let's dig in üëá

https://t.co/AD7ZRRu2iZ

@fuckyourputs @llllvvuu @0xkrane @0xcoli @crypto_noodles @MLGavaudan @dydxprotocol @AntonioMJuliano @perpprotocol @CrocSwap An unhedged LP position is like a short put.

A ~50% hedged LP position is a perfect straddle.

A 100% hedging a LP position is a naked call.

You can test it out yourself here: change the hedge H factor from 0 to 1 to see the different payoffs https://t.co/gZ2ND0OftS

RT @EthereumDenver: Riding the Unicorn: Uniswap v3 as a Perpetual Option Primitive by @guil_lambert  https://t.co/uqQzbnGko8

@llllvvuu @0xdoug There is no external market to trade Uni v3 positions, so yeah fees have to reflect some measure of realized volatility.

Someone could lend out the LP position for a fixed fee based on their predicted IV and the borrower will pay IV now and receive fees=RV from the position.

@llllvvuu @0xdoug IV is based on fee accrual of a 1-tick LP position and comparing the returns to a corresponding ATM option. Nothing to do with IL

The actual expression is 

IV = 2*feeTier*sqrt(24hVolume/tickLiquidity)

Here‚Äôs how I derive it: https://t.co/Xpf8CfFEHO and https://t.co/rM26RG6SrJ

@llllvvuu @0xdoug Several options traders that use geometric Brownian motion models to price options need a word with you.

How widespread is JIT though? I see no JIT mint/burn events on etherscan in the ETH-USDC pools in the past several hour even though many transactions are >$100k in size (?)

@0xkydo A real mining rig in his house I think. He just built the setup 6mo ago. 

He tried to shill me some other coin he was going to mine when I told him his setup wasn‚Äôt gonna work in 6 months
Took an Uber on my way to #ETHDenver, turns out the driver is running an Ethereum miner but he had no idea the merge is coming‚Ä¶

Lazy LPing is the same as selling an ATM put option that expires years (decades?) in the future

That's a fine strategy, albeit not for everyone.

Ultimately, Uni v3 doesn't "destroy" any strategy, it simply gives more control over the level of risk LPs are willing to take https://t.co/jT9mIYvfuA
@X3Finance @sjwill99 @lesigh3100 @Uniswap How?

@0xdoug But you're right about fees in high vol regimes. 

We can look at the IV of the ETH-USDC trading pairs on https://t.co/jo44yJuhnp: 

‚Ä¢1% pool: IV = 137%
‚Ä¢0.3% pool: IV = 96%
‚Ä¢0.05% pool: IV = 82%

Since returns are proportional to IV, high fee pools benefit the most right now

And the best way to not get rekt is to stay small. This is not for everyone, never invest more than your willing to lose, etc etc.

@0xdef1 @eulerfinance @AlphaFinanceLab Token deployment is permissionless on Euler.

https://t.co/VgmQEEtqlN

@ivangbi_ @NoahZinsmeister @eulerfinance Token deployment is permissionless on Euler, so new tokens will be available to borrow much more quickly than on other platforms. 

https://t.co/VgmQEEtqlN
@alpinechicken @haydenzadams viz. https://t.co/VLOPGynPwW

@kyoronut @eulerfinance LP positions only have positive profit/loss or negative profit/loss.

P&L is what needs to be hedged, impermanent loss doesn't exist üôÉ

@AseemSood_ Yes. But it will only be profitable if you expect the price to increase again, so the overall assumption is bullish in the long term despite a short-term bearish bout.

Participating in truly bearish pools (go to zero type of tokens) will not be a good strategy unless hedging.

8/8  Permissionless lending on @eulerfinance is a game changer:

-LPs can participate in all pools whether bullish/bearish/neutral
-Uniswap users will trade on more liquid pools 
-Depositors will earn more yields on @eulerfinance due to Uni LP borrowing

Win-win-win üëè

7/8  Delta-neutral LP positions can also be deployed in Uniswap v3. 

In this case, the liquidity provider will have to borrow H tokens, which is slightly less than 50% of the position's value, and lock the borrowed token with ETH at the middle of any range r (Price/r, Price*r) https://t.co/swjcQETEP8

6/8  LPs that hold a truly bearish perspective on an asset may even deploy a bearish LP position by borrowing 200% of the token and selling a part of it so that they can lock it at 50:50 ratio.

eg. borrowing 400 UNI tokens, selling 200 for 1 ETH and locking them in ETH-UNI pool. https://t.co/SxUCKX3ppQ

5/8  Concretely, a delta-neutral position in Uniswap v2 is realized by borrowing 100% of the token and locking in the same value of ETH or stablecoin. 

eg. borrowing 200 UNI tokens and locking them with 1 ETH in the ETH-UNI Uni v2 pool creates a delta-neutral LP position. https://t.co/ECVD7MBmWQ

4/8  As an alternative to LM, liquidity providers should have the opportunity to provide liquidity with an asset borrowed on @eulerfinance instead of buying it outright

That's because shorting an asset can be used to create delta-neutral and bearish LP positions in Uniswap v2/v3

3/8  As a result, LPs should simply withdraw all assets from bearish pools in order to protect their portfolio‚Äôs value.

Liquidity mining can offset some of these losses, but LM is not sustainable and could lead to the price spiraling down due to a selling feedback loops.

2/8  The problem with liquidity providing is that only pools with a bullish token are profitable.

That's because the value of a LP position has a positive delta and it will follow the price of the asset.

Token ‚¨ÜÔ∏è, LP value goes up
Token ‚¨áÔ∏è, LP value goes down https://t.co/ZSD03SJwuS

I just published "How to deploy delta-neutral liquidity in Uniswap‚Ää‚Äî‚Ää or why Euler Finance is a game changer for LPs" 
https://t.co/rqCgyL3V8e

@getty_hill @tzhen @labsGFX Many my colleagues actually worked at Bell Labs in the 1980s and 1990s, hit me up if you'd like to know more about how it operated.

@tzhen ‚òùÔ∏èeverybody at Bell Labs was heading their own 1-person research lab. No support staff or overhead

It was easy to collaborate because you could simply walk up to your neighbor and ask them for advice. 9 times out of 10 you were talking to the actual world expert on that subject

@tzhen The problem is not getting research funding. Many agencies will happily give you 0.5 to 2.5 million dollars if your proposal is good enough

Rather, we need to find a way to emulate Bell Labs: fund 100s of talented individuals to do what the hell they want, no strings attached.

@0xkydo @mxwtnb @p_e @tarunchitra @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans üëÜThe professor is wrong once again: I've made a mistake above when converting between r and Pb/Pa.

The correct expression should be:
Slippage = (Order Size)/(Total TVL)*ln(r^2)

Which reduces the slippage to 1.39%, a bit closer to @mxwtnb's answer.

@0xkydo @ribbonfinance 2- Price: there will be downward pressure on the price with liquidity mining & liquidity will leave after the $2M incentive ends

Maybe subsiding liquidity is better? Lend $RBN from treasury to LPs as a form of leverage ie. LPs deploy ETH but access 2x liquidity w/ $RBN matching

@bax1337 @reflexerfinance That's a good start, but prescribing specific upper+lower bounds doesn't work for non-stablecoin pools. 

The minWidth parameter still allows LPs to deploy positions centered around any price as long as tickUpper-tickLower > minWidth

Liquidity incentives are broken in Uni v3: 1-tick positions perform extremely well, but only if you're an ultra-active whale

I forked staker contract (<10 lines diff) to require that staked positions have a minimum width to address the 1-tick LM issues:

https://t.co/oIknvAJnVN https://t.co/60kD5dbEih
